stem: An 88-year-old female is admitted with new-onset extreme lethargy, apparent depression, and loss of appetite. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two most appropriate actions, and the two most important parameters to monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Assessment for sub-acute metabolic crisis in an elderly client.
Background: History of Graves' disease (diagnosed 20 years ago). Lapsed follow-up.
Assessment: Client is slumped in her chair, appearing weak and apathetic.
Recommendation: Immediate thyroid panel and cardiac rhythm check.

tabs.title: Geriatric Endocrine Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Serum TSH< 0.01 (Critically Low)Extreme Hyperthyroidism
Mental StatusApathetic; Dull; DepressedParadoxical CNS Response
Weight10 lb loss in 2 weeksHypermetabolic state
Heart RhythmAtrial Fibrillation w/ RVRHR 138 bpm

actionOptions.text: Administer IV Propranolol to control heart rate

parameterOptions.text: Level of consciousness and oral intake

rationale.correct: The patient is experiencing Geriatric Apathetic Thyroid Storm (c2). Elderly patients with thyroid storm often present with apathy, lethargy, and depression, rather than the agitation seen in younger patients. The critically low TSH and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) confirm a hypermetabolic crisis. Priority actions include managing the heart rate with a beta-blocker (a1) and continuous cardiac monitoring (a2). Key parameters to monitor are cardiac stability (p1) and mental status/nutritional intake (p2).
clinicalPearls: Apathetic thyroid storm has a high mortality rate because symptoms can be mistaken for normal aging or other conditions.
Tachycardia or atrial fibrillation is often the only classic hyperthyroid sign present.
Propranolol can help block the conversion of T4 to T3.

questionTrap.trap: Treating this as myxedema coma due to the patient's lethargy.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Consider the heart rate. Myxedema coma (hypothyroidism) causes bradycardia, while thyroid storm (including apathetic) causes tachycardia or atrial fibrillation.

mnemonic.title: Old Storm Cold
mnemonic.expansion: Patient looks SAD, but the T3/T4 is MAD (High). HR is fast, it's a thyroid blast.
